Maximizing AI with Cursor: Building MCP Servers for Seamless Workflow

Jump To

  • üïí Introduction and Welcome
  • üïí MCP Server Development Overview
  • üïí Initial Coding Challenges
  • üïí Task Management Tools
  • üïí Engineering Journal Vision
  • üïí Future Development Plans

Resources

  • Cursor - AI-powered code editor
  • Kubernetes - Container orchestration platform
  • Model Context Protocol - MCP specification and implementation

Key Takeaways

  • Start Simple, Learn Deeply: Whitney began with just Cursor to understand its raw capabilities before layering on tools
  • Tool Selection: Choosing supplementary tools such as Memory or Taskmaster should align with specific workflow needs
  • MCP Servers Enable Structure: A journal-generating MCP server can meaningfully document progress and enhance reflection
  • Structured Problem Solving: Breaking down tasks into smaller units aids in maintaining organization within complex projects
  • Dynamic Documentation: Keeping comprehensive records of project flows enhances both personal learning and project continuity

Summary

In this in-depth conversation, Whitney Lee shares how a weekend of ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù with Cursor spiraled into building her own MCP (Model Context Protocol) server‚Äîdesigned to automate the creation of engineering journal entries from Git commits, AI chats, and terminal commands.

With a background in Kubernetes and platform engineering‚Äîbut not recent app development‚ÄîWhitney walks through the creative and technical decisions behind her playful demo app and the real problem it helped her solve: tracking her technical progress and decisions with context, clarity, and reflection.

She explores:

  • Why she started with raw Cursor and deliberately held off on using MCP tools
  • The specific challenges she encountered‚Äîlike lack of memory, unclear documentation sourcing, and staying on task
  • How tools like Taskmaster, Memory, and Context 7 helped address those issues
  • Her vision for a journaling MCP server that automatically generates daily, weekly, and monthly summaries‚Äîcomplete with tone, milestones, terminal history, and reflections
  • How she designed and validated the architecture using AI-driven dialogue, test-driven development, and zero-trust principles

This episode offers a real-world look at how AI tooling can support‚Äînot replace‚Äîhuman thinking, and how to shape those tools into something genuinely useful and sustainable.

Full Transcript

Scroll or use controls to navigate
üí° Tip: Click on the üïí icons above or timestamps in the transcript below to jump to that point in the YouTube video. 
[00:00:00] **Jason Hand:** Hey, Whitney, how's it going? 

[00:00:01] **Whitney Lee:** So great. I'm so happy to be here. 

[00:00:04] **Jason Hand:** Awesome. It's great to have you here. So what kind of stuff are you gonna show us today? 

[00:00:07] **Whitney Lee:** Oh, I have caught the AI bug in a big way. So I'm gonna talk about how I've sussed out my AI workflow and how I've been inspired to build an MCP server and what that looks like.

[00:00:20] **Jason Hand:** That's fantastic! Can you tell us a bit about your background and what led you to this project?

[00:00:25] **Whitney Lee:** Sure! My background is actually in Kubernetes and platform engineering. I haven't done much app development recently, but I got really interested in how AI could help with documentation and tracking technical decisions. I spent a weekend just playing around with Cursor - what I call 'vibe coding' - and that's when the idea for this MCP server started taking shape.

[00:00:45] **Jason Hand:** So what exactly does your MCP server do?

[00:00:48] **Whitney Lee:** It's designed to automate the creation of engineering journal entries. It pulls together Git commits, AI chat history, and terminal commands to create a comprehensive record of what you're working on. The goal is to help engineers maintain better context and reflection about their work.

[00:01:10] **Jason Hand:** That's really interesting. What made you start with just Cursor instead of jumping straight into using MCP tools?

[00:01:15] **Whitney Lee:** I wanted to understand the baseline experience first. When you start with raw Cursor, you quickly run into certain limitations - like the lack of persistent memory, unclear documentation sources, and difficulty staying focused on complex tasks. This helped me identify exactly what problems I needed to solve with my MCP server.

[00:01:40] **Jason Hand:** And how did tools like Taskmaster and Memory help address those issues?

[00:01:45] **Whitney Lee:** They were game-changers. Taskmaster helped break down complex tasks into manageable chunks, while Memory gave me that crucial persistent context I needed. But the real magic happened when I started thinking about how to combine these capabilities into something that could automatically generate daily, weekly, and monthly summaries of my work.

[00:02:10] **Jason Hand:** Can you tell us more about how you approached building the server?

[00:02:15] **Whitney Lee:** I took a very methodical approach. I used AI-driven dialogue to validate my architecture decisions, implemented test-driven development from the start, and applied zero-trust principles throughout. The goal was to create something that wasn't just a cool demo, but a genuinely useful tool that could enhance how developers document and reflect on their work.

[00:02:40] **Jason Hand:** This seems like a great example of using AI as a complement to human thinking rather than a replacement.

[00:02:48] **Whitney Lee:** Exactly! It's about augmenting our capabilities, not replacing them. The AI helps capture and organize information, but the real value comes from how it enables better human reflection and decision-making. It's about creating tools that work with our natural workflow rather than forcing us to adapt to the tool.

[00:03:05] **Jason Hand:** So what's next for the project?

[00:03:08] **Whitney Lee:** I'm working on making it more robust and user-friendly. I want to add better visualization of the data, improve the natural language processing for better summaries, and maybe even add some predictive features that can help identify patterns in how we work. But most importantly, I want to keep it focused on enhancing human capabilities rather than replacing them.

[00:03:30] **Jason Hand:** This has been fascinating, Whitney. Thanks for sharing your journey with us.

[00:03:34] **Whitney Lee:** Thank you!
